STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 13, 2023
Ahmad Sabbagh
Livingston County DHHS
2300 E. Grand River Suite 1
Howell, MI, 48843-7577
RE: License#: CP470201250
Dear Dr. Sabbagh:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Services

homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
The DHHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
must be completed for every FTM.
One of six foster care files had a FTM without a completed 1105 report.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Borrowed beds- The agency was provided with the business process for
managing borrowed beds in CWLM.
• Parent Agency Treatment Plans- When PATPs are provided to parent/foster
parents via mail, the foster care worker must also document attempts to
obtain a signature on the PATP.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
• One special evaluation found that a foster parent changed the formula of a
medically fragile child, without permission. This foster parent was providing respite

care and had been fully trained on the child's needs. Revocation of the license was
recommended.
• The second special evaluation was due to allegations a foster parent exposed
himself and made inappropriate comments to a foster child. Revocation of the
license was recommended.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The CAP, approved 10/4/22, was the result of the 9/25/22 interim evaluation. The
CAP addressed one violation regarding participation of parents/foster parents in
development of treatment plans. During the current review it was determined the
agency is in compliance with their CAP. No repeat violations were found.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) was reviewed and discussed. The
CAA indicated the agency successfully implemented their 10/4/22 CAP. The
agency utilized the quality improvement team, training, and the Book of Business
to monitor compliance with the CAP. During this review, there were no repeat
violations found. The Chief Administrator reported that the number of foster care
cases is moving in a downward trend across the county. Likely due to increased
services to maintain kids in their home of origin. The agency reported some
difficulties over the past year with retaining and hiring staff, placement
emergencies, and an overall lack of response from some clients regarding visits
and parenting time. Despite this, the agency continues to maintain a high level of
compliance.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed. Both staff reported being with the agency for over a
year. Both staff stated they enjoy their jobs and have excellent supervisors. One
staff reported some challenges this year included new licensing rules, learning a
new computer system for licensing, and a new system for foster parent inquiries.
However, staff reported feeling supported and having the resources needed.
Neither staff had any concerns or recommendations for how to improve the
agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2022 review. The
building is easily accessible and has sufficient space for staff and clients. The
office has adequate locking storage for confidential materials.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ ___________October 9, 2023_________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 13, 2023
_____________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
